content.title: Eversion Carotid Endarterectomy
content.description: A technique for carotid endarterectomy where the internal carotid artery is transected, everted, and the plaque removed by everting the arterial wall inside-out.
content.definition: Eversion CEA involves transecting the ICA at its origin, everting the artery like removing a sock, performing endarterectomy of the everted vessel, then reimplanting the ICA to the CCA. Advantages include no patch requirement, shorter clamp time, and ability to correct redundancy/kinking.

technique_steps: Transect ICA at bulb origin obliquely
Evert ICA over dissector or forceps
Remove plaque as cylinder as artery everts
Reimplant ICA to CCA (may shorten for redundancy)
advantages: No patch material required (reduced infection risk)
Avoids suture line at critical bifurcation
disadvantages: May be difficult with high ICA lesions
Not ideal for very calcified plaque
outcomes: Perioperative stroke/death rates equivalent to conventional CEA
Possibly lower restenosis rates (no patch narrowing)
Shorter operative time in experienced hands

learning_objectives: Compare advantages vs conventional CEA with patch
clinical_pearls: Endpoint must be confirmed by palpation and direct vision
Can shorten redundant ICA by removing arterial length
Not suitable if plaque extends >3cm into ICA
Some surgeons prefer eversion for all cases; others reserve for redundancy
